{{also|tag|TAG|tág|tåg}} ==Alemannic German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|gsw|tag|tàg|tog}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|gsw|gmh|tag}}, {{m|gmh|tac}}, from {{inh|gsw|goh|tag}}, {{m|goh|tac}}, from {{inh|gsw|gem-pro|*dagaz}}. Cognate with {{cog|de|Tag}}, {{cog|nl|dag}}, {{cog|en|day}}, {{cog|is|dagur}}, {{cog|sv|dag}}, {{cog|got|𐌳𐌰𐌲𐍃}}. ====Noun==== {{head|gsw|noun|g=m}} # {{lb|gsw|Uri}} [[day]] ====Related terms==== * {{l|gsw|Täg}} ===References=== * {{R:Urseren|14}} {{topics|gsw|Astronomy|Time}} ---- ==German== [[File:Rotating earth maxi.gif|thumb|280px|Ein siderischer '''Tag''' der Erde. — A sidereal Earth '''day'''. (3)]] [[Image:Berlin-zentrum-by-RalfR-026.jpg|thumb|280px|Reichs'''tag''' (9)]] ===Pronunciation=== {{attention|de|please clarify whether "only colloquial for younger speakers" means "only used colloquially and by younger speakers" or "only used colloquially when used by younger speakers"}} * {{IPA|de|/tɑːk/}} {{a|Germany, Austria}} * {{IPA|de|/tax/}} {{a|northern Germany and parts of central Germany; often only colloquial for younger speakers}} * {{IPA|de|/tɑːx/}} {{a|parts of central Germany; Franconia, Lower Bavaria; often only colloquial for younger speakers}} * {{IPA|de|/tɑːɡ̊/}} {{a|Switzerland, Austria}} * {{a|Germany}} {{audio|de|De-Tag(de).ogg}} * {{hyphenation|de|Tag}} * {{rhymes|de|aːk|ax|aːx}} ===Etymology 1=== From {{inh|de|gmh|tag}}, {{m|gmh|tac}}, from {{inh|de|goh|tag}}, {{m|goh|tac}} (attested since the 8th century); from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*dagaz}}, from {{inh|de|ine-pro|*dʰegʷʰ-||to burn, to be illuminated}}. Germanic cognates include {{cog|osx|dag}} (whence {{cog|nds-de|Dag}}), {{cog|odt|dag}} (whence {{cog|nl|dag}}, {{cog|af|dag}}), {{cog|ang|dæġ}} (whence Modern {{cog|en|day}}), {{cog|fy|dei}}, {{cog|non|dagr}} (whence {{cog|is|dagur}}, {{cog|fo|dagur}}, {{cog|no|dag}}, {{cog|sv|dag}}, {{cog|da|dag}}), {{cog|yi|טאָג}} and {{cog|got|𐌳𐌰𐌲𐍃}}. Non-Germanic cognates include {{cog|sq|djeg||to burn}}, {{cog|la|foveo||to warm, nurture}}, {{m|la|favilla||cinders, ashes}}, {{cog|grc|τέφρα}}, {{cog|lt|dãgas||hot season}}, {{cog|ru|жечь||to burn}}, {{cog|sa|दहति||to burn|sc=Deva}}. Although they are similar in appearance and meaning, {{cog|de|Tag}} and {{cog|gem-pro|*dagaz}} are not related to {{cog|la|diēs}} as older [[folk etymologies|folk etymology]] suggested; instead, the {{noncog|la|-}} word is derived from {{noncog|ine-pro|*dyeu-}}, {{m|ine-pro|*dyew-||to shine}}. See the {{noncog|lv|diena||day}} and {{noncog|sa|दिन|tr=diná||day|sc=Deva}} for more.Wolfgang Pfeifer, ''Etymologisches Wörterbuch des Deutschen'' (1995, 2005; München: dtv; {{ISBN|3423325119}} {{etystub|de|How did Sense 9 (Reichstag) come about?}} ====Noun==== {{de-noun|m|Tages|gen2=Tags|Tage}} # {{lb|de|countable}} [[day]] {{gloss|24-hour period}} # {{lb|de|countable}} [[day]] {{gloss|period from midnight to the following midnight}} #: ''Der '''Tag''' fängt um Mitternacht an.'' — The '''day''' begins at midnight. # {{lb|de|countable|astronomy}} [[day]] {{gloss|rotational period of a planet, moon or any celestial body (especially Earth)}} # {{lb|de|countable}} [[day]], [[daylight]] {{gloss|period between sunrise and sunset when there is daylight}} #: ''Im Winter sind die '''Tage''' kürzer.'' — During the winter the '''days''' are shorter. #: ''Diese kurzen '''Tage''' verursachen Depressionen.'' — These short '''days''' cause feelings of depression. #: ''An den irdischen Polen dauert ein '''Tag''' sechs Monate'' — At the Earth's poles a '''day''' lasts about six months. # {{lb|de|uncountable}} [[day]], [[daylight]], [[light]] {{gloss|light from the Sun}} # {{lb|de|uncountable|figurative}} [[light]] {{gloss|open view; a visible state or condition}} # {{lb|de|uncountable}} [[day]] {{gloss|part of a day which one spends at work, school, etc.}} #: ''Nun, wie war dein '''Tag'''?'' — Well, how was your '''day'''? #: ''Überstunden!? Was für ein '''Tag'''!'' — Overtime!? What a '''day'''! # {{lb|de|uncountable|figurative}} [[day]] {{gloss|specified time or period, considered with reference to the prominence or success (in life or in an an argument or conflict) of a person or thing}} #: ''Der '''Tag''' gehört uns. Gut gemacht, Männer!'' — ''It's our '''day''', now. Well done, men!'' #: ''Heute ist einfach nicht mein '''Tag'''.'' — ''It's just not my '''day'''.'' # {{lb|de|countable|dated|now found chiefly in compounds such as [[Reichstag|Reichs'''tag''']] or [[Landtag|Land'''tag''']]}} [[convention]], [[congress]] {{gloss|formal assembly}} # ''see'' '''[[Tage]]''' ''for plural-only senses'' =====Declension===== {{de-decl-noun-m|(e)s|e}} =====Hyponyms===== {{col4|de |Montag |Dienstag |Mittwoch |Donnerstag |Freitag |Samstag |Sonnabend |Sonntag |Geburtstag |Glückstag |Sankt-Nimmerleins-Tag |Tag der Arbeit |Jüngster Tag |Ruhetag |Schalttag |Schöpfungstag |Stichtag |Weltgerichtstag |Wochentag }} =====Derived terms===== {{col4|de |auf den Tag |auf den Tag genau |in acht Tagen |Reichstag |Tag und Nacht |Tagebau |Tageblatt |Tagebuch |tagelang |Tagelöhner |Tagesausblick |Tagesereignis |Tagesnachrichten |Tagesrückschau |Tagesschau |Tageszeitung |täglich |Tagtraum }} =====Related terms===== * {{l|de|tagen}} =====Descendants===== * {{desc|hrx|taach}} ====See also==== * {{l|de|Mitternacht}} * {{l|de|Nacht}} * {{l|de|Mittag}} * {{l|de|Nachmittag}} * {{l|de|Abend}} * {{l|de|Woche}} ===Etymology 2=== Abbreviation of the greeting {{m|de|guten Tag||good day}}. ====Interjection==== {{head|de|interjection}} # {{lb|de|colloquial}} [[hello]]; (good) [[day]] ===References=== [[Category:de:Units of measure]] ---- ==Polish== ===Proper noun=== {{head|pl|proper noun|g=m}} # [[Tagus]] (river in Iberia) ====Declension==== {{pl-decl-noun-sing|Tag|Tagu|Tagowi|Tag|Tagiem|Tagu|Tagu}} [[Category:pl:Exonyms]] [[Category:pl:Rivers]] [[Category:pl:Spain]]
